results.headline: A Heartbreaking Loss for One and All

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Bridegroom

results.summary_short: “Bridegroom,” directed by Linda Bloodworth-Thomason, is about an unmarried gay couple in their 20s and the hardships faced by one of the men when the other dies in an accident.

results.headline: Living and Killing in a Materialist China

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of A Touch of Sin

results.summary_short: In “A Touch of Sin,” the director Jia Zhang-ke presents four stories, based on real events, that illustrate a country’s social and political upheaval.

results.headline: Development Comes With Downsides in Cambodia

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of A River Changes Course

results.summary_short: “A River Changes Course,” a documentary about Cambodia from Kalyanee Mam, looks at environmental degradation and urban migration.

results.headline: Sell Them Trees, Then Steal Them Blind

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of All is Bright

results.summary_short: Paul Giamatti and Paul Rudd play professional thieves attempting to give up crime in “All Is Bright,” a new film directed by Phil Morrison.

results.headline: Advice From Elders Rivets a Couple on the Path to Marriage
results.display_title: Walter: Lessons from the World's Oldest People

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Walter: Lessons from the World's Oldest People

results.summary_short: In “Walter: Lessons From the World’s Oldest People,” Hunter Weeks and Sarah Hall ask about keys to longevity.

results.headline: Swimming With White Horses Away From the Battlefield

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Vikingdom

results.summary_short: “Vikingdom” could best be described as a cross between a violent video game and a black light fantasy poster.

results.headline: Friends Come Together for an Intervention

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Last Day of August

results.summary_short: Friends try to stage an intervention for an alcoholic buddy holed up at his family’s old cabin upstate in Craig DiFolco’s “Last Day of August.”

results.headline: Something Creepy This Way Comes

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Nothing Left To Fear

results.summary_short: Things are far from pastoral when a preacher moves his family to a small town in “Nothing Left to Fear,” directed by Anthony Leonardi III.

results.headline: A Shooting Star Lights Up Manhattan

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Linsanity

results.summary_short: “Linsanity,” Evan Jackson Leong’s documentary, looks at how Jeremy Lin became a basketball sensation.

results.headline: Fleeing Her Troubles for a Host of New Ones

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of I Used to Be Darker

results.summary_short: “I Used to Be Darker” is an intimate journey through the lives of an unraveling family.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Running Wild: The Life of Dayton O. Hyde

results.summary_short: “Running Wild: The Life of Dayton O. Hyde” tells how one man created a horse sanctuary.

results.headline: One Holds the Cards, the Other Is Bluffing

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Runner, Runner

results.summary_short: In “Runner Runner,” Justin Timberlake joins Ben Affleck in running an offshore Internet gambling site.

results.headline: Taking the Stigma Out of Dyslexia

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Disleksia: The Movie

results.summary_short: “Dislecksia” is a humorous documentary about a serious subject: what dyslexia is and how to treat it.

results.headline: Is There Really a Market for That?

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Concussion

results.summary_short: In “Concussion,” by Stacie Passon, a woman finds an escape from the tedium of her marriage by becoming a prostitute catering to other women.

results.headline: Anything for a Laugh

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Besharam

results.summary_short: Ranbir Kapoor stars as a thief in the romantic comedy “Besharam.”

results.headline: Stress Brings Out a Real Monster in Him

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Bad Milo!

results.summary_short: In the comedy “Bad Milo!” Ken Marino plays a mild-mannered accountant with a vengeful critter living in his colon.

results.headline: Love Triangle, With Mom in the Middle

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Babygirl

results.summary_short: Macdara Vallely’s “Babygirl” centers on a teenager who is trapped in a love triangle with her mother’s boyfriend.

results.summary_short: Thomas Kretschmann stars in “Argento’s Dracula 3D,” a film directed by Dario Argento.

results.headline: Newcomer’s Rite of Passage

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Five Dances

results.summary_short: In “Five Dances,” Ryan Steele plays a young dancer who goes through a newcomer’s rite of passage at a New York dance company.

results.headline: A Hit Maker by Any Name

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of A.K.A. Doc Pomus

results.summary_short: “A. K. A. Doc Pomus” focuses on the life of the writer of several early rock ’n’ roll successes.
